title: Abstract classes are classes that are meant to be inherited but avoid implementing specific methods, leaving behind only method signatures that subclasses must implement.

inline_content.Text: Abstract classes are classes that are meant to be inherited but avoid implementing specific methods, leaving behind only method signatures that subclasses must implement.

title: Abstract classes are useful for defining and enforcing class abstractions at a high level, similar to the concept of interfaces in typed languages, without the need for method implementation.

inline_content.Text: Abstract classes are useful for defining and enforcing class abstractions at a high level, similar to the concept of interfaces in typed languages, without the need for method implementation.

title: One conceptual approach to defining an abstract class is to stub out the class methods, and then raise a NotImplementedError if accessed. This prevents children classes from accessing parent methods without overriding them first. Like so:

inline_content.Text: One conceptual approach to defining an abstract class is to stub out the class methods, and then raise a NotImplementedError if accessed. This prevents children classes from accessing parent methods without overriding them first. Like so:

title:
class Apple(Fruit):
    pass


a = Apple()
a.check_ripeness() # raises NotImplementedError

content_resolved.code:
class Apple(Fruit):
    pass


a = Apple()
a.check_ripeness() # raises NotImplementedError

title: Creating an abstract class in this way prevents improper usage of methods that are not overriden, and certainly encourages methods to be defined in child classes, but it does not enforce their definition. With the
abc
c
module we can prevent child classes from being instantiated when they fail to override abstract class methods of their parents and ancestors:
